1 point: For substituting the work done on the block by friction with the table (i.e., the energy lost to heat as the block slides to rest on the table)
Ki – Fbdn – ƒTD = 0

The initial kinetic energy of the projectile is the same as in the first case when the block was clamped. Therefore, it can be equated to the work done in stopping the projectile from part d.

1 point: For substituting Fbd for the initial kinetic energy of the block

Fbd – Fbdn – ƒTD = 0
Fbdn = Fbd – ƒTD

Full credit could not be earned for just writing this equation. The student needed to have some indication that the work-energy relationship was being applied, and that Fd was associated with the initial kinetic energy.
